titleStmt.title: Musarum deliciae Contayning more then a select century of royall Latine anagrams, besides diverse written in English, upon the sacred name and titles of our dread soveraigne and of his dearest consort, and their most princely progeny. Together with apposite anagrams upon all the English monarchs that have lived and died since the union of the royall roses and houses of Yorke and Lancaster. Some few of those extracted from his Maiesties imperiall name, have been heretofore presented to his royall hands with gracious acceptance. The Latine anagrammes are expressed in English verses in the opposite columne. Perused anew, and now published altogether, (with the authors assent) by Arthur Pyne Esquire, to whom the anagrams made in honour of the Prince his Highnesse were in speciall manner directed.
titleStmt.author: Pyne, John, d. 1644.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 37 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 9 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Musarum deliciae Contayning more then a select century of royall Latine anagrams, besides diverse written in English, upon the sacred name and titles of our dread soveraigne and of his dearest consort, and their most princely progeny. Together with apposite anagrams upon all the English monarchs that have lived and died since the union of the royall roses and houses of Yorke and Lancaster. Some few of those extracted from his Maiesties imperiall name, have been heretofore presented to his royall hands with gracious acceptance. The Latine anagrammes are expressed in English verses in the opposite columne. Perused anew, and now published altogether, (with the authors assent) by Arthur Pyne Esquire, to whom the anagrams made in honour of the Prince his Highnesse were in speciall manner directed.
titleStmt.author: Pyne, John, d. 1644.
Pyne, Arthur.

notesStmt.note: Running title reads: Royall anagrams expressed in English.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-10 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2011-07 Kayla OndracekText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: CONTAYNING MORE then a ſelect Century of royall Latine Anagrams, beſides diverſe written in Engliſh, upon the ſacred name and titles of our Dread Soveraigne and of his deareſt Conſort, and their moſt Princely Progeny.
Together with appoſite Anagrams upon all the Engliſh Monarchs that have lived and died ſince the union of the royall roſes and houſes of Yorke and Lancaſter.
Some few of thoſe extracted from his Maieſties Imperiall Name, have been heretofore preſented to his Royall hands with gracious acceptance.
The Latine Anagrammes are expreſſed in Engliſh verſes in the oppoſite Columne.
Peruſed anew, and now publiſhed altogether, (with the Authors aſſent) by Arthur Pyne Eſquire, to whom the Anagrams made in honour of the Prince his Highneſſe were in ſpeciall manner directed.

lg.l: Carole qui triplicis fulges diademate Regni,
Ter populo dilecte, Deo dilecte ter-uni;

(Virgil. Semper honos nomen
que tuum laudes
que manebunt;)
Scripta tuam accipias in laudem, nomen, honorem.

l.hi: Great Charles with three rich diadems high-crowned,
Thrice lov'd of men, the Trinities delight;
For your great
l.note: Like Gods peculiar people, high in praiſe and in name, and in honour. Deut 26.19.
l.hi: honour, name, and praiſe renowned:
In praiſe of your moſt honour'd name I write.

div.head: To the Queenes Maieſty.
div.l: Great Queene, great Britaines other greater light;
My Muſe (although leaſt worthy) here brings forth
Choice Anagrams (in which French wits delight)
To teſtifie her ſervice, and your worth.

lg.l:
Haeredum flos ſumme, haeres digniſſime
•• ſorum & liliorum. florum,
Ecce tibi, Princeps, Muſarum flosculus horti
Ad Tamiſim à Tamarae margine miſſus adeſt.

l.hi: You
l.note: He alludeth to the flowring moneth of May in which the Prince was borne.
l.hi: flow'r of Princes whom French lillyes ſhield,
And the faire roſes of theſe Britiſh Realmes;
Accept ſome flow'rs of the Pierian field,
From
l.note: The author liveth neere the bankes of Tamar.
l.hi: Tamar brought to Thames the Prince of Streames.

div.head: To the Duke of Yorke.
div.l: Iames now is what Charles was in th'unions Spring,
Yorkes duke deſcended from the royall race:
Charles is what Iames then was, the Soveraigne King
Of all this Iſland, through Gods Soveraigne Grace.
Sith th'heav'ns are pleas'd thus to tranſpoſe great names;
Deigne your acceptance to theſe Anagrams.

div.head: To the Lady Mary.
div.l: Moſt princely Lady, ſome poeticke Layes,
Preſuming on your leave, I here advance
To you, who raiſed are to be the praiſe
And ornament of Britaine and of France.
My chaſte Muſe free's from feares of juſt offence,
Clad (like your infant yeeres) in innocence.

div.head: The fourefold Anagram following compareth the Kings Maieſty for his princely literature to the Laurell, the crowne of learning; for his rare eminency and conſtant piety, to the Cedar, whoſe lea • e never falleth, and whoſe fruit never faileth; for the gracious br • ghtneſſe of royall maieſty, to the morning inlightening and enlivening the earth; and for all perfections of grace and government, to that ſacred and learned king Alured, otherwiſe called Altred, whoſe valour and vertue are ſo highly extolled by our hiſtorians.

l.hi: Like the faire laurell you appeare,
You like the goodly Cedar ſpread:
But you ſhine at the morning cleere,
A ſacred King like Alured.

div.p: In the next Anagram his maieſty is moſt fitly likened to that gotlly and gracious king Oſwald, whoſe name (ſaith our Antiquary)'s equivalent in ſignification with Steward. This Oſwald having beene baptized among the Scots was afterward crowned King ouer the Engliſh, and (ſo Bede writeth) did cauſe this whole Iſland to flow with peace and flouriſh with plenty.

l.hi: Like deare Saint Oſwald whom hiſtorians found
In Scotland chriſtend and in England crown'd.

div.p: Other Anagrams acknowledging his ſacred Maieſty to be as the cleare light, and the deare delight of his loyall people.

l.hi: Enrich'd with heau'ns rare dower, continue ſhining;
Like th'high plac'd Sun in power, not in declining.

lg.l: Carolus primus Steuardus totius Albionis Rex ſereniſſimus.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Noſtra lux or ſuet uſu clariſſima, nos ſi deſeris tu, peribimus.

l.hi: Our light whoſe ray and riſing doth us cheriſh;
Should you away, we drown'd in teares muſt periſh.

div.p: The two following Anagrams, the latter of which is contryved into an exact hexameter and pentameter verſe, doe declare his majeſty to be the beauty and ſafety, the ornament and the muniment of his dominions.

lg.l: Carolus Stevvardus Angliae et Scotiae Monarcha.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Suorum decor, ac genti ſuae laeta ſalutis anchora.

l.hi: He under God his great Protectour, ſtand.
As th'ornament and anchor of his Lands.

lg.l: Carolus primus Stevvardus, et Anglorum, et Scotorum Rex ac Monarcha ſereniſſimus.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Arx ſuprema ſuis, ſummus decor, anchora grata,
Cor, turris, columen, lumen et eſto ſuis.

l.hi: His peoples ſtay, their refuge, and ſafe fort,
Their heart, their eye, their beauty, and ſupport.

div.p: Hi • Maieſties royall marriage with the Lady Mary Burbon was thus celebrated in Heroicall Anagrammaticall verſes, and in ſundry other Anagrams to them annexed.

lg.l: Carolus primus Angliae et Scotiae Monarcha.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Carus amore cito, ac Gallis pius, enthea Norma.

l.hi: His nuptiall loue was deare and undelayd;
Hee to the French an heav'nly rule and ayd.

lg.l: Carolus unitae Angliae et Scotine Monarcha.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Sic volat alina, venit caſtae Regina coronae.

l.hi: The faireſt Queene came flying on loves wing
Vnto the crowne of Charles the chaſteſt king.
He having taken her to wife, will make her
Of moſt aboundant happineſſe partaker.
Thus knowne and knit vnto his peereleſſe Queene,
A pious Husband he hath ever beene.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Carolus Stevvartius Angliae et Scotiae Monarcha.
Ter carae Gallae vita et honos.

l.hi: Like Numa, Curius and Cato chaſte;
Her life and honour whom his love embrac'd.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Conſtans Mariae turtur haberis, vnica viola.

l.hi: The Turtle deere that to his Peere
hath conſtant love expreſt;
The violet that heav'n did ſet
for Maries faireſt breaſt.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Nova norma ſancti et caſti amoris.

l.hi: Whoſe modeſt looke and life are rules to move
Our looſer times to learne a chaſter love.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Sic turſus virtus ipſa amorum excellens
et alta viret, bina corda nectens.

l.hi: Wee now behold (like thoſe of old)
loves higheſt power to raigne,
Which in this faire and high borne paire
hath made one heart of twaine.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Sunt Muſis aevo hoc natis verè aurea ſecla,
Nam Regum caſtis lilia iuncta roſis.

l.hi: The golden age, as I preſage,
Shall now the Muſes nouriſh;
Sith with the Roſe the Lilly grow's,
and being crown'd doth flouriſh.

lg.l: Carolus I. Steuartius vnitae Angliae Scotiaequè Monarcha.

l.hi: The tender Lilly through loves chaſte device,
Enioyes the pleaſant Roſes cordiall iuyce.

div.p: The heavenly protection extended towards his Maieſty through the whole courſe of his life is thus anagrammatically acknowledged.

lg.l: Carolus Steuartius et Rex et Monarcha Angliae.

l.hi: O king on earth triumphing! from above,
You, the triumphant Angels guard and love.

div.p: The late deplored condition of his Maieſties exiled onely Siſter was thus commiſerated in an Anagram.

l.hi: Why ſhall his ſacred Siſter thus remain
An exile and expos'd to foes diſdaine?

div.p: The following Anagrams were compoſed in relation to his Maieſties moſt pious and vertuous endowments, which make him parallel to the moſt famous Princes, and pretious to his loyall people.

l.hi: His lot befell him in the faireſt field.
Hee's under God, our Churches onely ſhield.
His loyall Subiects healthfull heart and mirth;
Renowned both for enterpriſe, and birth.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Tuae et ara gentis ac oculus:

l.hi: His peoples refuge, love and ſweet delight,
Breath of their mouth, and of their eyes the light.
Who ſtand's the more renown'd in mens opinions
For ioyning vertues great with large dominions.
A Conſtantine unto the Chriſtian Muſes;
The fair'ſt and dear'ſt Prince that the world produces.
Whom all true-hearted Britons doe confeſſe
To be th'Augmenter of their happineſſe.
Their ſafe health, and their ſtrength and heart is he.
O let him as the Roſe preſerved be!

lg.l: Carolus primus Stevvartus validissimè potens vuitae Angliae et Scotiae Monarcha.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Carum adeò cor, vita, salus Anglis venit; Ipsi
Mars venit, et Muſae, Clio, Arethuſa, potens.

l.hi: When he our ſo deare heart, life, health bècame,
Breath of our noſtrils, glory of his name:
Mars and the Muſes with Diana's mate
Came to him to attend his royall State.

lg.l: Hiberniacquè Monarcha ter honoratissimus, et munificentissimus; valdè acer ac mitus

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: En fecit noſtris Is ſanè haec otia Musis:
Nam laudi eſt huic mitis amor, nequè forma fereno
Ipsi, nec virtus rara, fidesvè deeſt.

l.hi: Loe thus the glory that our king hath won,
Gave ſpurre to my dull verſe, and made it run.
For, gentleneſſe, faith, • ew • y, vertues rare,
Crowne Charles the
l.note: Titles given by hiſtorians to the royall name of Charles.
l.hi: wiſe, the welbelou'd, the faire.
Mercy and Truth have met in him as Mates,
He cal's true hearts, and cruel arts he hate's.

div.head: The Queenes Maieſty is compared in the ſix fold Anagram following to the Turtle for her conjugall chaſtity and fidelity; to the Aſian myrrhe and Phaenix for her incorrupt ſincerity, and ſingular excellency, and concluded to be a moſt gentle and gracious Lady.

l.hi: Shee's mate vnto a Turtle faire,
A faithfull wife and ever true.
Shee's of her ſexe the Phenix rare,
And like Myrrhe which in Aſia grew.
A Lady, of all men belov'd,
Moſt gentle, excellent, approv'd.

div.p: The royall aboundance of the Queenes vertues, and her earneſt deſire to bynde the Britiſh and French ſcepters in an everlaſting league, together with our devout prayers that ſhee may flouriſh like the pleaſant Vine in her royall branches, and long liue with her Lord, the King, have occaſioned this fourefold Anagram,

l.hi: Vertues faire Altar, richly furniſhed,
You royally will ancient kingdomes wed.
O let this pleaſant Vine her branches ſpread,
And never deck a

note.l: Et ſemper natis gaudeat illa tribus.

l.hi: ſecond husbands bed!

div.p: Vpon her Maieſties admired vertues, mildneſſe, beauty, royall deſcent; happy marriage, peace-loving diſpoſition, rare perfection and excellent ſharpeneſſe and ripeneſſe of wit and judgement, theſe Anagrams have beene written.

l.hi: A iuſt Aſtraea you have ever beene,
Iuſtly admired, and moſt royall Queene.
Haile Lady taking no delight in war,
Moſt calme and comely, gracious and rare.
Haile worthieſt Queene in wit excelling far,
You to your traine Minerva's Altar are.
Borne of a royal houſe, and growne
l.note:
like Maud the Empreſſe who was alſo the daughter of an Henry, of whom we reade Magna ortu, maier
que Viro—
l.hi: great ſince,
By being the Spouſe of ſo renoun'd a Prince.

lg.head: Anagramma
lg.l: Regali or natu ſum margarita nivea.

l.hi: For royall ornaments deſerving praiſe,
As the white orient pearle of theſe our dayes.

lg.l: Maria Stevvard vnitae et Angliae ac Scotorum Regina.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Alma Ceres, et Iuno grata, arguta Minerva!

l.hi: Fruitfull as Ceres, for a gracefull gate
Like
Iuno, for ſharpe wit Minerva's mate.
Your ſelfe you ſhew (through all your life)
To be a Foe to warre, and ſtrife.
Your love to peace that lovely mak's,
Staye's crownes and altars which warre ſhake's.
You in true ripeneſſe of perfection ſhine,
Like perfit gold dig'd from the pureſt Mine.

div.p: Of the Queenes thriſe amiable countenance and admirable carriage winning affections at firſt view, theſe Anagrams have beene written.

l.hi: This gracious Queene of all approv'd,
Where ſhee's once ſeene, is thrice belov'd.
A Lady meerely for great worth affected,
Belov'd ſincerely, worthily reſpected.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Amati digna es vt rara, Angelica.

l.hi: Love's precious Iemme, the deare delight of all;
Beauties bright beame, rare, faire, Angelicall.
O how attractive are her vertuous parts,
The load-ſtone and the load-ſtarre of mens hearts.
Shee's chaſte as Veſta, and vpon fames wing
Mounts higher, marryed to the chaſteſt king.

div.head: The great Bleſſings which Great Britaine hopeth to enioy in her young Prince Charles have beene anagrammatically expreſſed as followeth.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Tun' ut alba viris roſa ſua viter crescens?

l.hi: Like to the faire white roſe you doe ariſe,
Which ſo, delightfull growe's to all men's eyes.
Grow fayre and deare by grace and nature dreſſed,
And like a field with heav'nly fulneſſe bleſſed.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Cum veſtris iunge laurea ſerta rosis.

l.hi: Still with your royall engliſh roſes ioyne
The Laurell garland of the Arts divine.
Grow deare through learned arts (while wars wax cruell)
Bee in this iron age a golden Iewell.
Grow faire and flouriſh, and freſh odours yeeld,
Deck'd like the roſe that doth adorne the field.
Moſt nobly iuſt, and for ca • h art renown'd,

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Is aptè ornatus, clarus, Angelicus puer.

l.hi: From heaven fitly furniſh'd to be crown'd,

lg.head: Anagramma
lg.l: Ille novus, purus, ac reparatus Alcides

l.hi: In whom Alcides is reſtor'd a new,
Strengthned with vertue, vices to ſubdue.

div.p: In the following Anagrams the Prince as the hopefull heyre of his royall Fathers reſplendent vertu • s, is compared to thoſe glorious heavenly bodies the Sunne and Starres, and to thoſe renowned Princes of Britaine King Arthur and King Lucius, of whom the former hath his name derived from that northerne fixed ſtarre Arcturus, and the latter from the light which the Sunne ſhed's upon the earth, &c.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Essicut Arthurus ac verè Sol Britannis.

l.hi: Yare like Prince Arthur in our Britiſh Story,
And like the Sun riſing in perfit glory.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Ortus an is iuuenis praeclarus páce Britannis

l.hi: Shining from th'youthfull Spring with radiant rayes,

lg.l: Vpon the Britons in faire peacefull dayes.
Carolus Princeps Stuartius Borboniusquè, et proles Britannica.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Ac orbi Princeps Lucius ortus erat.

l.hi: In you both we and all the world have won
Another
l.note: Lucius Rex, agnomine magni ſplendoris. Nennius.
l.hi: Lucius, yea another Sun.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Tu rarus orbi Natus, principale ſanè decus.

l.hi: A rare ſonne borne vnto the world, and ſent
To be its honour and chiefe ornament.
Deare as the Sun which from the heav'n doth ſhine;
Cleare as the Starrs, and every way divine.
Thou cleareſt Starre now riſing in the North,
The load-ſtar of the Chriſtian Worlds affection:
Spreading bright beames of rareſt Princely worth,
Stand fix't, and give to Sea and land direction.
Shining in graces and in vertues here,
Such a deare luſtre to the Britons give,
(Till thou reach heav'n like to a Starre moſt cleere)
That in that light they may ſee how to live,
Hee's fit to rule, then whom no Turtle's chaſter,
Whom chaſtity it ſelfe ſhall rule and maſter.
Our Royall Rachel link't with Iacobs heire
Long truſted for a princely propagation,
Till God fulfill'd unto that happy Paire
Both Rachels truſt, and their realmes expectation.
When this young Prince from Charles his loynes deſcended,
Then Rachels mourning for loſt iſſue, ended.
A true ſure Caſtle providence divine
Hath given to Britaine ſince her civill warres.
Princes deſcended from the regall line
Are ſorts 'gainſt forreigne foes, and homebred jarres.
Your ſteps (if you your Parents paths regard)
Shall vertues trace: vertues ſhall you reward.

div.head: The happy expectation raiſed by the birth of the Duke of Yorke, hath beene attended by the following Anagrams.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Svavi ego virtute crescens Muſis rosa habebor.

l.hi: Behold the roſe that (as the Muſes ſay)
Moſt ſweetly growes in vertue every day.
Planted at Yorke through honours princely due,
Where anciently the royall white roſe grew.
O deare, O bleſſed Babe, borne to encreaſe
Your Parents hopes, your Countryes happineſſe.

lg.head: Anagramma
lg.l: Tunè pius ac caſtus Puer Orbis?

l.hi: Mirrour of pious and chaſt moderation
To all the world in happy expectation!
Follow your Grand-ſire (as your name doth bynde you)
So ſhall your followers a
iuſt maſter finde you.
Wee in the fountaines whence you ſprang, deſcry
That you ſhall flow with ſtreames of wit moſt cleare,
That vertue, bewty, and rare maieſty
Shall you endow, and to the World endeere.

div.head: The great hopes that Great Britaines Inhabitants have conceived of the Lady Mary their Princeſſe, and the great loue they beare her, are ſet forth in the following Anagrams.

lg.head: Anagramm.
lg.l: Clara viris Dea, vita, amor et lepor.

l.hi: To Men you'le prove a goddeſſe bright,
Their life, their love, and their delight.
Pleaſing in ſhewing forth your mothers Grace.
Thrice lov'd for princely worth in every place.
Your mothers life, a childe whom Heav'n endeer's;
Borne to prolong the Parents golden years.

lg.l: De ter-foelicis et regalis tori prole, Maria Steuartia ac Borbonia.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Foelicitèr de alterâ orbis ſecuritate bonâ gloriari Maria potes.

l.hi: Well may you glory that you did ſupply
The World with other good
ſecuritie.

lg.l: Vnto the fayreſt Brittaine Lady, Mary Stevvard.

lg.head: Anagram.
lg.l: Art vertuously maintain'd by thy deareſt Father.

l.hi: Let golden vertues crowne your mayden dayes,
And in your nurture ſpred your Parents prayſe.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Al doe admire at thy vertues.

l.hi: You are in riſeing worth and vertues rare,
Like that chaſte Delian Mayd Diana fayre.

div.head: Anagrams upon all the Engliſh Monarches that have lived and dyed ſince the union of the royall roſes and houſes of Yorke and Lancaſter; from Henry the ſeventh ſurnamed Theodore alias Tider, the author of that happy union, unto Iames the firſt, the bleſſed vniter of the kingdomes of Great Britaine.

lg.head: Anagr.
lg.l: Tu roſis numen eras ac decor optimus.

l.hi: You were that power which did both roſes raiſe,
Adorning them with faire and peacefull dayes.

lg.head: Anagramma duplex.
lg.l: 1. Tu roſis decor, ac ope tuâ munimen Anglis eras.
2. Tu notus unione rosis pacem declaras regiam.

l.hi: To th'Engliſh Roſes which did long diſſent,
You were a ſafegard and an ornament.
Fame ſpread's your worth, whoſe wiſdome did connect
The Roſes, and a royall peace effect.

lg.head: Anagramma
lg.l: En viramatus! O decor Anglis, ac novus Hector!

l.hi: Loe he was Englands beautious love and praiſe,
And like another Hector in his dayes.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: En dulcis arvus Dei dextrâ riguus!

l.hi: This Prince like ſome faire plot of pleaſant land,
Was water'd euery jot with Gods right hand.

lg.head: Anagramma
lg.l: Oh genti molli dura! An mot igero amata?

l.hi: Hard to the milde! Biller in indignation
To the obedient childe! Oh where's compaſſion?
This royall Maid, in Belgia's great diſtreſſe.
Was her re • itſe, her ayde, her Governeſſe.
Though foes aroſe, ſhe had a joyfull raigne:
God did revenge her cauſe; their force reſtraine.

lg.head: Anagramma.
lg.l: Rectiùs (ô!) doctus chartis, Legis pia meta,
Norma fuit Musis, ac pacis vi, Hic, bonus Aſa!

l.hi: Through learnings better helpes be ſought to hound
Strict Lawes within right limits. Him we found
A Rule vnto the Muſes, and inveſted
With peace, like
l.note: The Land had reſt and he had no warre. 2 Chron. 14.6.
l.hi: Aſa, when all Iudah reſted.
